body:
Hi @frankiechang123 can you please describe how you installed it; if you used the pip install deeplabcut-docker you will get the gui version wrapped as needed; i.e.. follow here:https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/docker.html

as an aside:
`pip install deeplabcut` is the headless version; `pip install deeplabcut[gui]` is the GUI version. 
also see this issue: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1618

rename.to: `Cannot load backend 'WXAgg' which requires the 'wx' interactive framework, as 'headless' is currently running`

body:
Thank you for your reply!

I tried to directly pull the image and create a container in hope that I could use the deeplabcut package as normal inside the container, but it gives the error message as above when I import it in python.

I also tried using the `deeplabcut-docker` tool, as you suggested, but it gives a similar error message when I run `deeplabcut-docker gui`:

```
$ deeplabcut-docker gui

                    .--,       .--,
```

hi @frankiechang123 but this: `Failed to launch the DLC GUI. Used args: "-e DISPLAY=unix -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix -v :/home/developer/.Xauthority -v /home/frankiechang123:/app -w /app "
Container stopped.` is the same error message as the other issue I linked; the solutions are:

(1) are you running this without a screen? / virtual machine / remote? that won't likely work. 
(2) you need to enable xhost, from the other post, you need to run:

`echo $DISPLAY`
`xhost + $IP`

and post the result: i.e., see here: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1618#issuecomment-997114388, then I can help ;)

rename.from: `Cannot load backend 'WXAgg' which requires the 'wx' interactive framework, as 'headless' is currently running`
rename.to: `Failed to launch the DLC GUI. Used args: "-e DISPLAY=unix -v /tmp/.X11-unix:` [duplicate issue]

body:
I'm attempting to run this on Ubuntu WSL2 in Windows. I was able to connect WSL2 to a X server on Windows, and `echo $DISPLAY` gives `172.18.96.1:0.0`, `xhost + $IP` gives `access control disabled, clients can connect from any host`.

Then running `deeplabcut-docker gui` gives:
```
ImportError: Cannot load backend 'WXAgg' which requires the 'wx' interactive framework, as 'headless' is currently running
[2021-12-27T15:25:20-0800]: Failed to launch the DLC GUI. Used args: "-e DISPLAY=unix172.18.96.1:0.0 -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix -v :/home/developer/.Xauthority -v /home/frankiechang123:/app -w /app "
Container stopped.
```

Currently, my WSL2 is able to run GUI applications(like firefox etc.) From my understanding, all the DLC GUI container needs to do is just to connect its GUI application to the display, right? Is there something else I could try?

Thank you!
sorry for delay, yes, that is true, but setting the IP for the screen might be harder; I have no exp. in a linux sim. windows, case, sorry!

issue.title: ImportError: Cannot load backend 'WXAgg' which requires the 'wx' interactive framework, as 'headless' is currently running

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Bug description

After a fresh install of docker for my ubuntu 18.04 system, I successfully pulled the deeplabcut-latest-gui-jupyter image from Dockerhub.  However, when I call 'deeplabcut-docker gui' on my terminal I get the following output:
> "ImportError: Cannot load backend 'WXAgg' which requires the 'wx' interactive framework, as 'headless' is currently running
[2022-04-27T12:14:09-0700]: Failed to launch the DLC GUI. Used args: "-e DISPLAY=unix -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix -v :/home/developer/.Xauthority -v /home/carmen:/app -w /app "
Container stopped.

I'm wondering if this has anything to do with the fact that I don't have an NVIDIA GPU, and I haven't been able to install an NVIDIA driver for that reason.  I'm also new to WSL and Ubuntu, so possibly I am just misunderstanding some basic installation concept.  Any help would be greatly appreciated!

### Operating System

Ubuntu 18.04

### DeepLabCut version

N/A

### DeepLabCut mode

single animal

### Device type

Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) on Windows 11 Home 64-bit
Intel(R) UHD Graphics

### Steps To Reproduce

In Ubuntu 18.04:

> from https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/ubuntu/:
``` 
 sudo apt-get update
 sudo apt-get install \
    ca-certificates \
    curl \
    gnupg \
    lsb-release
curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/docker-archive-keyring.gpg
echo \
  "deb [arch=$(dpkg --print-architecture) signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/docker-archive-keyring.gpg] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu \
  $(lsb_release -cs) stable" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/docker.list > /dev/null
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io docker-compose-plugin

```
After running `sudo docker run hello-world` I get the correct message printed.

> from 	https://hub.docker.com/r/deeplabcut/deeplabcut/tags:

```
docker pull deeplabcut/deeplabcut:latest-gui-jupyter'
```

> Install DLC helper, finish other setup steps

```pip install deeplabcut-docker
sudo groupadd docker
sudo usermod -aG docker $USER
sudo reboot
deeplabcut-docker gui
```

### Relevant log output

```shell
.--,       .--,
                    ( (  \.---./  ) )
                     '.__/o   o\__.'
                       `{=  ^  =}´
                         >  u  <
 ____________________.""`-------`"".______________________
\   ___                   __         __   _____       __  /
/  / _ \ ___  ___  ___   / /  ___ _ / /  / ___/__ __ / /_ \
\ / // // -_)/ -_)/ _ \ / /__/ _ `// _ \/ /__ / // // __/ /
//____/ \__/ \__// .__//____/\_,_//_.__/\___/ \_,_/ \__/  \
\_________________________________________________________/
                       ___)( )(___ `-.___.
                      (((__) (__)))      ~`

Welcome to DeepLabCut docker!

Container stopped.
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issue.title: Segfault during Kmeans for frame selection

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Bug description

Similar issues #1651 and #1809 exist, but the proposed solutions fail in my case. 

Here's what I did:
1. When using the latest version of conda to create an environment using the `DEEPLABCUT.yaml` file provided, `wxpython` failed to build. Full stdout and stderr here: [conda_create_out.txt](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8887086/conda_create_out.txt)
2. Following `setup.py`, I added  `wxpython<4.1` as a conda-supplied dependency to [DEEPLABCUT2.yaml](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8887097/DEEPLABCUT2.txt). This solves the problem of `wxpython` not building. 
3. I get the OpenBLAS segfault during frame extraction, as reported by #1651 and #1809. The solution in #1651 was just to use the supplied environment file, which I am already doing. The solution in #1809 was to install scipy and scikit-learn with conda instead of pip. 
4. Following #1809, I added `scipy` and `scikit-learn` to [DEEPLABCUT3.txt](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8887104/DEEPLABCUT3.txt). I hoped this would work, since I know that `conda-forge` often builds with different compiler options that better support CPUs with large numbers of cores. Full output from env creation [here](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8887109/conda_create_out_3.txt). Sadly, I continued to get the same error, though now with a mangled stack trace and a SIGSEGV:
    ```
    Kmeans clustering ... (this might take a while)
    ...
    BLAS : Program is Terminated. Because you tried to allocate too many memory regions.
    *** Received signal 11 ***
    *** BEGIN MANGLED STACK TRACE ***
    Segmentation fault (core dumped)
    ```
    Output from  `python -m threadpoolctl --import sklearn` (also attached below, in the "Device type" section):
    ```
    [
      {
        "user_api": "blas",
        "internal_api": "openblas",
        "prefix": "libopenblas",
        "filepath": "/home/gfindlay/miniconda3/envs/datoviz/lib/python3.8/site-packages/numpy.libs/libopenblas64_p-r0-2f7c42d4.3.18.so",
        "version": "0.3.18",
        "threading_layer": "pthreads",
        "architecture": "SkylakeX",
        "num_threads": 64
      },
      {
        "user_api": "blas",
        "internal_api": "openblas",
        "prefix": "libopenblas",
        "filepath": "/home/gfindlay/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/scipy.libs/libopenblasp-r0-8b9e111f.3.17.so",
        "version": "0.3.17",
        "threading_layer": "pthreads",
        "architecture": "SkylakeX",
        "num_threads": 64
      },
      {
        "user_api": "openmp",
        "internal_api": "openmp",
        "prefix": "libgomp",
        "filepath": "/Volumes/scratch/neuropixels/t2_shared_envs/dlc_shared_t2/lib/libgomp.so.1.0.0",
        "version": null,
        "num_threads": 224
      }
    ]
    ```
    Note that the OpenMP `num_threads` is 224. 
5. #1809 referenced [this](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/20539) scikit-learn issue, which further references [this](https://github.com/xianyi/OpenBLAS/issues/3321) OpenBLAS issue. See in particular [this](https://github.com/xianyi/OpenBLAS/issues/3321#issuecomment-885433142) comment. Since the `MiniBatchKMeans` that DLC uses does not offer an `n_jobs` kwargs like `DBSCAN` or `KNN` do, I set my `OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS` and `OMP_NUM_THREADS` environment variables to 64. Didn't fix anything. In fact, `htop` sugggested that these variables were being ignored. I wondered if they might influence builds and not just runtime behavior (similar to `MAX_THREADS`), so I recreated the env. No luck. Perhaps importantly, there is no change to the output of `python -m threadpoolctl --import sklearn`. 
6. I took the extreme route and set `OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS` and `OMP_NUM_THREADS` to 1. No luck. Again, no change to the output of `python -m threadpoolctl --import sklearn`. This makes me really wonder if the `OMP_NUM_THREADS` environment variable is being ignored. Maybe `omp_set_num_threads()` is overriding `OMP_NUM_THREADS`? I know this is possible, but usually is only done to _decrease_ the number of threads... I don't know of any other way to control OpenMP threading behavior. 

Unfortunately we have tried a containerized install as well, but cannot get the GUI to work on our remote servers using either rootless or rooted Docker. We are not yet clear on whether this is an issue with how the DLC container handles graphical displays or how Docker per se handles remote displays. Quite possibly the latter. Perhaps related to #1623. We will probably just give up and use local workstations for the GUI, and hope to at least get a containerized headless install working so we can train on the server GPU. 

Sorry I can't be more helpful! And sorry that this really is probably not an issue with DLC per se, but it seems to be affecting users, so I thought you might like more info. Thanks for DLC :

### Operating System

Ubunutu 20.04.4 LTS

### DeepLabCut version

2.2.1

### DeepLabCut mode

single animal

### Device type

I have an NVidia Tesla V100 32GB GPU, but I am attempting a conda-based CPU-only install on a 224-core Intel Xeon Platinum 8276M (Skylake, x86_64). For detailed info, see `lscpu` output [here](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8887072/lscpu_out.txt).
 
As expected, `nproc` reports 224, `joblib.cpu_count()` reports 224, and `joblib.cpu_count(only_physical_cores=True)` reports 112. 

Here's the output of `python -m threadpoolctl --import sklearn`, which I suspect is highly relevant:
[threadpoolctl_out.txt](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8887127/threadpoolctl_out.txt)

### Steps To Reproduce

See above. 

### Relevant log output

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
